questions.text: Find the structure in this figure whose paralysis results in a reduction in breathing motions.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: A
 
  • The structure in the figure that is labeled A is the phrenic nerve.
  • The phrenic nerve is responsible for innervating the diaphragm, which is the major muscle of breathing.
  • The phrenic nerve carries motor signals from the brain to the diaphragm, stimulating its contraction and promoting inhalation.
  • Paralysis of the phrenic nerve will result in a reduction in breathing motions and may result in respiratory difficulties or even respiratory failure, depending on the extent of the nerve damage.
  The other structures in the figure are the following:
  • B: Thyrocervical artery
  • C: Inferior thyroid artery
  • D: Vagus nerve

questions.text: Which nerve may be involved in the malformation seen below?
questions.solution:
This image is showing partial Claw hand sign which is seen in Ulnar nerve damage.

Ulnar nerve supplies
1. 3rd and 4th Lumbricals 
2. Palmar and Dorsal interossei

3/4th lumbrical are required for PIP and DIP extension at 4th/5th digits, and 4th/5th digit flexion at MCP joint.
Hence, ulnar nerve damage will lead to flexion at 4th/5th digit PIP and DIP joints, and extension at  4th/ 5th digit MCP joints leading to partial ulnar claw hand.




Note: The image given is not of Benediction(Pope) sign. In Benedict sign (which occurs due to median nerve damage) - there is loss of 1st and 2nd lumbricals (which helps in 2/3rd digits MCP Flexion) - leading to extension at index/middle finger MCP joint. But since 3/4th lumbrical are spared - there is flexion at 4/5th digit MCP joint. 
The main difference is at 4/5th digit MCP joint - In ulnar claw hand - 4/5th digit MCP joint would be extended; while 4th/5th digit MCP in benedict sign(median nerve injury) would be flexed. 




Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 984,984.e1

questions.text: The nucleus is where the receptor for hormone X is determined to be located. What could possibly be X?
questions.solution:
Thyroxine is a lipophilic hormone that acts on nuclear receptor. “Steroids and thyroid hormones are distinguished by their predominantly intracellular sites of action, since they can diffuse freely through the cell membrane. They bind to a family of largely cytoplasmic proteins known as nuclear receptors. Upon ligand binding, the receptor–ligand complex translocates to the nucleus where it either homodimerizes, or associates with a distinct liganded nuclear receptor to form a heterodimer. In either case, the dimer binds to DNA to either increase or decrease gene transcription in the target tissue.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 482.

Leptin accelerates GnRH pulsatility in Hypothalamic neurons, fastening puberty.

Thus, leptin is said to be having a permissive action.

questions.text: Chest wall and lung recoil are balanced in a relaxed condition at:
questions.solution:
FRC( functional residual capacity)

Elastic recoil is defined as the ability of a stretched or inflated Lung to return to its resting volume (FRC).

Elastic recoil of the lung is directly related to lung stiffness, that is, the stiffer the lung, the greater the elastic recoil (but lower compliance).

The lung volume at which elastic recoil of lung and elastic recoil of chest wall are at equilibrium (i.e. equal elastic recoil force but in opposite directions) is represented by FRC.

questions.text: When rising from a seated position, a person's blood pressure drops by 10 mm Hg. After correction, the baroreceptor increases the blood pressure by 8 mm Hg with a 2 mm Hg mistake. What benefit does the system provide?
questions.solution:
Gain of a Control System is the degree of effectiveness with which a control system maintains constant conditions.

Gain= Correction/Error 

Correction = 8 mm Hg

Persisting error after correction = 10-8 = 2 mm Hg

Hence, Gain = 8/2 = 4.

questions.text: Which one of these amino acids does not enter the Krebs cycle by forming Acetyl CoA via pyruvate?
questions.solution:
Amino acids enter the Krebs cycle through various pathways, and some do so by being converted into pyruvate, which is then transformed into Acetyl CoA. Here's how these amino acids are metabolized:

  1. Glycine:

    • Glycine can convert into serine, which is then metabolized to pyruvate.
    • Enters the Krebs cycle via pyruvate → Acetyl CoA.

  2. Tyrosine:

    • Tyrosine is broken down into fumarate and acetoacetate. These products enter the Krebs cycle but not through pyruvate or Acetyl CoA.
    • Does not use the pyruvate pathway.

  3. Hydroxyproline:

    • Hydroxyproline is derived from proline and can be converted into pyruvate.
    • Enters via pyruvate → Acetyl CoA.

  4. Alanine:

    • Alanine is transaminated directly to pyruvate.
    • Enters via pyruvate → Acetyl CoA.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 160.

questions.text: A toddler who accidentally ingested cyanide is sent to the hospital. It prevents the citric acid cycle by preventing:
questions.solution:
Cyanide blocks Complex IV (Cytochrome oxidase) of Electron transport Chain. It has no direct effect on any component of Citric acid cycle. If the electron transport chain is blocked, then the electron carriers NADH and FADH cannot unload their electrons into it, which means NAD+ and FAD are not regenerated. Since Glycolysis and the Krebs cycle both require NAD+ (and the Krebs cycle requires FAD), NAD+ will get depleted and NADH level is raised, both of these processes will stop running.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: A patient presented with a 4 months’ history of cough with diarrheal episodes. Bronchoscopy revealed an intrabronchial polyp. Biopsy from the polyp showed atypical cells with microscopic necrosis and 5 mitotic figures per 10 high-power fields as shown below. Chromogranin staining was positive. What is the diagnosis and grade of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Atypical carcinoid grade 2

  • The patient has carcinoid syndrome, according to this clinical situation.
  • Chromogranin positivity supports the tumor's neuroendocrine origin. The difference between typical and atypical carcinoids is that typical carcinoids have less than two mitoses per ten high-power fields and do not exhibit necrosis, whereas atypical carcinoids have between two and ten mitoses per ten high-power fields and/or necrotic foci.
  • These have been categorized as grade 2 carcinoids.
  • As a result, the patient has a Grade 2 Atypical Carcinoid. Atypical carcinoids also show increased pleomorphism, have more prominent nucleoli, and are more likely to grow in a disorganized fashion and invade lymphatics.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 723.

questions.text: A kidney specimen that was removed is displayed below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Flea-bitten kidney of malignant hypertension
 
  • The image shows a kidney with multiple small hemorrhages, resembling a "flea-bitten" appearance.
  • This finding is characteristic of malignant hypertension, where severe hypertension causes damage to the renal blood vessels leading to hemorrhages.
* Other options:
 
  • Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis typically presents with glomerular changes such as glomerular hypercellularity and crescent formation, which are not observed in this image.
  • Chronic glomerulonephritis is characterized by chronic inflammation and fibrosis in the glomeruli, which is not seen in this image.
  • Amyloidosis would show amyloid deposits within the kidney, which are not evident in this image.

* [Extra Edge]: Nephritic syndromes


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2091.

questions.text: How should RBC be transfused?
questions.solution:
Packed RBCs after removal from refrigerator (in blood bank) should be transfused within 4 hours. The cannula diameter for transfusion of blood in adults should be 18-20 gauge.

The 30-minute rule states that red blood cell (RBC) units left out of controlled temperature storage for more than 30 minutes should not be returned to storage for reissue; the 4-hour rule states that transfusion of RBC units should be completed within 4 hours of their removal from controlled temperature storage,



Reference: Brunskill, Susan et al. “What is the maximum time that a unit of red blood cells can be safely left out of controlled temperature storage?.” Transfusion medicine reviews vol. 26,3 (2012): 209-223.e3. doi:10.1016/j.tmrv.2011.09.005. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22119493/

  • Rabeprazole is exclusively metabolized by CYP2C19 and does not cause any inhibition of CYP450.
  • Among the PPIs, only omeprazole inhibits CYP2C19 (thereby decreasing the clearance of disulfiram, phenytoin, and other drugs) and induces the expression of CYP1A2 (thereby increasing the clearance of imipramine, several antipsychotic drugs, tacrolimus, and theophylline).


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: One can observe black deposits on the conjunctiva of glaucoma patients upon using:
questions.solution:
Adrenochrome deposits are common after chronic use of topical epinephrine for glaucoma.

One classic cause is oxidation of epinephrine drops, which can lead to conjunctival deposits of adrenochrome, a melanin-like pigment accumulation.



Reference: Domarus D. Adrenochromeinlagerungen in die Kornea ("Schwarze Hornhaut"). Klinisch-pathologischer Fallbericht [Adrenochrome deposits in the cornea ("Black cornea"). A clinical-pathological case report]. Ophthalmologica. 1977;175(3):166-70. German. doi: 10.1159/000308650. PMID: 896145.

questions.text: Which of these is not a G2 phase blocker?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Paclitaxel

  • Paclitaxel (PTX) is a taxane. It is an M-phase blocker.
  • PTX binds to microtubules instead of tubulin dimers and stabilizes microtubules (polymerization) by promoting the assembly of alpha and beta tubulin subunits, the building blocks of microtubules.

questions.text: What is L-asparaginase used to treat?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) ALL

L-asparaginase is used in the treatment of ALL (Acute lymphoblastic leukemia).

Mechanism of Action
L asparaginase depletes asparagine in lymphoblasts and lower levels of cellular asparagine cause reduced RNA, DNA, and protein synthesis. This leads to the inhibition of cell growth and later cell death. 

Drugs used in the treatment of ALL
 
Phase of Treatment Drugs used
Induction Steroids, Vincristine, L-asparaginase, Daunorubicin
Consolidation Cyclophosphamide, Cytosine Arabinoside
CNS Directed Therapy Intrathecal Methotrexate/CNS irradiation
Maintenance Oral 6MP/Methotrexate

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 928.

questions.solution:

  • Thienopyridine antiplatelet agents interfere with platelet activation and aggregation induced by ADP.

  • Telmisartan undergoes biliary excretion, can be given in CRF
  • Losartan increases Uric acid excretion (use – hypertension + gout), blocks thromboxane A2

questions.text: Mediators of ganglionic transmission include:
questions.solution:
Ganglionic transmission is mediated by nicotinic receptors present postsynaptically. In both divisions of the autonomic nervous system, postganglionic neurons express nicotinic acetylcholine receptors to receive signals from preganglionic neurons. The neurotransmitters of postganglionic fibers differ. In the parasympathetic division, neurons are cholinergic (that is, acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter).

In the sympathetic division, neurons are mostly adrenergic (that is, epinephrine and norepinephrine function as the primary neurotransmitters). 


Reference:https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10864965/

choices.text: Alpha-1 agonist action leading to peripheral vasoconstriction
Increase in renal perfusion due to agonist action on D1 receptors
Releases noradrenaline and causes positive inotropic effect
Direct action on heart via beta-1 receptors

questions.text: Which of the following dopamine characteristics is not beneficial in acute shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Increase in renal perfusion due to agonist action on D1 receptors
 
  • Dopamine at low concentrations (2 to 5 mcg/kg per minute) primarily acts on vascular D1 receptors, especially in the renal, mesenteric, and coronary beds.
  • By activating adenylyl cyclase and raising intracellular concentrations of cyclic AMP, D1 receptor stimulation leads to vasodilation and reducing cardiac load. The net result is a decrease in blood pressure and an increase in cardiac contractility. 
  • Infusion of low doses of dopamine causes an increase in glomerular filtration rate and renal blood flow and Na+- K+ -ATPase pump. Increased renal perfusion and decrease in blood pressure caused by dopamine due to D1 agonism (at low doses) doesn’t improves survival in acute shock.
  • As circulating DA concentrations rise, DA is able to activate β adrenergic receptors to further increase cardiac contractility. At very high concentrations, circulating DA activates α adrenergic receptors in the vasculature, thereby causing vasoconstriction; thus, high concentrations of DA increase blood pressure, i.e, a concentration  of 10mcg/kg/min infusion.

Option 1, 3 and 4 all points towards a Vasoconstrictive action on vasculature and a positive inotropic effect on heart.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 298.

questions.text: What aspect of metoclopramide causes its antiemetic effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) D2 antagonist

  • Metoclopramide is a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist and is also a mixed 5-HT3 receptor antagonist & 5-HT4 receptor agonist.
  • The antiemetic action of metoclopramide is due to its antagonist activity at D2 receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone in the central nervous system-this action prevents nausea & vomiting triggered by most stimuli.
  • At higher doses, 5-HT3 antagonists' activity may also contribute to the antiemetic effect.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 713.

questions.text: Which action of adrenaline is not noticed when treating anaphylaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Action on presynaptic alpha-receptors
 
  • Adrenaline action on presynaptic alpha receptors (alpha 2) decreases its actions centrally by presynaptic inhibition and hence not helpful in management of Anaphylactic Shock.
  • The prejunctional α2 receptor activates Gi-protein which then inhibits neuronal Ca2+ channels and also limits the intracellular availability of Ca2+ by decreasing cAMP production. Transmitter (NA) release is consequently diminished. Hyperpolarization through activation of G-protein gated K+ channels may also occur.
  • The use of epinephrine in countering anaphylaxis represents functional antagonism. Functional antagonism refers to the inhibition of an agonist’s action downstream of the receptor.
  • Epinephrine increases cyclic AMP levels within bronchiolar smooth muscle cells, which in turn inhibits myosin light chain kinase and thereby diminishes the contractile response engendered by histamine, thromboxane A2, and other substances released by mast cells
  • The alpha 1 receptor agonism  by epinephrine causes vasoconstriction which counter acts the vasodilatation caused by histamine. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 145.

choices.text: Decrease in blood pressure on adrenaline administration after phentolamine has been given

questions.text: Which of these statements best describes Dale's vasomotor reversal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Decrease in heart rate on adrenaline administration after phentolamine has been given

Adrenaline is a both alpha and beta agonist and Phentolamine is an alpha blocker.
  • Administration of epinephrine (Adrenaline) after administration of α-blockers produces only a fall in BP. This is because the α-mediated response is abolished and hence, only the β-mediated response is seen, resulting in a fall in BP. This phenomenon is called the Vasomotor reversal of Dale. 
  • Vasomotor reversal of Dale is a blockade of alpha (α1) followed by stimulation of beta (β2) receptors.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.

questions.text: A clinical trial's post-marketing surveillance is a component of which stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Phase IV

* [Extra Edge]: Phase 4 of clinical trials

A type of clinical trial that studies the side effects caused over time by a new treatment after it has been approved and is on the market. These trials look for side effects that were not seen in earlier trials and may also study how well a new treatment works over a long period of time.

* Phase 1: First testing in humans, primarily to test safety. A drug is given to a small number of healthy volunteers who are closely monitored.

* Phase 2: Testing in a small number of patients, to assess safety, to monitor how a drug is metabolized, and to gather initial data on efficacy.

* Phase 3: A large trial in patients to test efficacy and safety. Pivotal phase 3 trials (or registration trials) provide the key data on efficacy in submissions for regulatory approval.

* Phase 4: Studies undertaken after a drug has been licensed, to gather further safety, efficacy or effectiveness data in routine clinical use.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 91.

questions.text: The following is an image of a 23 year old female. Her blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg, and she also has stiff neck. A lumbar puncture showed 4200 cells per microlitre, a protein level of 198, and a glucose level of 21 mg/dL. Which of the following statements about the organism responsible for this ailment is true?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram negative diplococci.
Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse - Friderichsen syndrome.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 232.

questions.text: All of the following can result in autoinfection, except:
questions.solution:
Autoinfection is the infection of a primary host with a parasite, particularly a helminth, in such a way that the complete life cycle of the parasite happens in a single organism, without the involvement of another host. Therefore, the primary host is at the same time the secondary host of the parasite.

Except Ascaris lumbricoides all the other options mentioned can cause auto infection.

questions.text: The following helminths have been linked to pernicious anaemia:
questions.solution:
The pernicious anemia is caused by the fish tapeworm, Diphyllobothrium latum.

D. latum contains considerable amounts of vitamin B12. The host and the living tapeworm in the intestinal canal compete for vitamin B12 leading to Pernicious anemia. There is parasite-mediated dissociation of the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex in the gut lumen making B12 unavailable to the host.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 120.

questions.text: Which of the following attributes makes CLED medium better than MacConkey agar?
questions.solution:
• CLED medium differentiates lactose fermenters from non-fer­menters and inhibits the growth of other commensals just like MacConkey medium. It allows urinary bacteria to grow and supports the growth of gram-positive bacteria (except hemolytic Streptococcus)and Candida. (Which McConkey does not) This attribute makes CLED medium better than MacConkey agar.
 
  • CLED agar (cystine lactose electrolyte deficient medium) is electrolyte deficient, hence, it also helps in preventing proteus swarming, this is the most important use of CLED agar. But proteus swarming can be prevented in MacConkey agar as well by reducing the concentration of sodium chloride. Therefore, it's not the reason for the superiority of CLED over MacConkey. 
 
  • MacConkey agar is a differential medium in which lactose fermenting( Eg E.coli) which stains pink color and Non lactose fermenting( Eg Shigella species, Salmonella) which do not change the color.
  • Contents of MacConkey agar - Peptone, Lactose, Agar, Neutral red, Sodium taurocholate.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 42.

questions.text: Which of the following is an intracellular parasite that is obligate?
questions.solution:
Ehrlichia is a genus of rickettsiales. Ehrlichia chaffeensis are small, obligately intracellular, endosomal bacteria. Persistent infection in reservoir white-tailed deer is transmitted by lone star ticks. Flu-like illness can progress to severe multisystem disease with toxic shock-like syndrome, meningitis, or ARDS.

other options:-

(1) Tropheryma whippelii - This bacterium causes Whipple’s disease and is an intracellular pathogen, but it’s not strictly obligate like Ehrlichia chaffeensis.

(2) Bartonella henselae - This is an intracellular bacterium that causes cat scratch disease but can also exist in the extracellular environment.

(4) Mycobacteria - While Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an intracellular pathogen, it is facultative, meaning it can survive both inside and outside of host cells under certain conditions.

So, Ehrlichia chaffeensis is the most appropriate choice as an obligate intracellular parasite.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 416.

questions.text: The short incubation period of transfusion-associated malaria is caused by the blood's inclusion of:
questions.solution:
Trophozoites are present in infected RBCs in humans. When they rupture at Schizont stage, they release merozoites into the blood stream. Hence packed RBCs will be infected with trophozoites and these are directly transmitted to the recepient's blood during transfusion and start dividing. This causes Malaria with a much lesser incubation period.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 80.

questions.text: At PHC, ABC and VED analyses are performed for:
questions.solution:
Important methods of inventory control include

  • A - B - C analysis
  • Periodic revision of classification
  • VED analysis.
 
  • VED analysis is based on critical values and shortage cost of the item. Based on their criticality, the items could be classified into three categories: Vital, essential and desirable, i.e., VED.
  • In materials management, ABC analysis is an inventory categorisation technique. ABC analysis divides an inventory into three categories—"A items" with very tight control and accurate records, "B items" with less tightly controlled and good records, and "C items" with the simplest controls possible and minimal records. 

Online reference: https://www.iptsalipur.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/BP703T_PP_V.pdf

questions.text: Pick the correct statement about Total Goitre Rate (TGR).
questions.solution:
The criteria of endemicity is a Total goitre rate of >10%.

Total goitre rate: Percentage of children aged 6-11 with palpable or visible goitre.
This is an indicator of iodine deficiency, which causes brain damage and mental retardation.

Classification of goitre—

Grade 0: no goiter is palpable or visible.
Grade 1: palpable goiter, not visible when neck is held in normal position.
Grade 2: a clearly swollen neck (also visible in normal position of the neck) that is consistent with a goiter on palpation.

Criteria for TGR endemicity is classified as mild (TGR 5–19.9%), moderate (TGR 20–29.9%), and severe (TGR > 30%). 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 738, 739.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best study design to assess in quick time the strength of the association between smoking and lung cancer?
questions.solution:
The quickest way to establish a cause-and-effect link is through case control. Clinical trials and cohort studies are more precise, but they also take much longer and cost more money.

Case control studies, often called “retrospective studies” are a common first approach to test causal hypothesis. In recent years, the case control approach has emerged as a permanent method of epidemiological investigation.
The case control method has three distinct features :

a. both exposure and outcome (disease) have occurred before the start of the study

b. the study proceeds backwards from effect to cause; and

c. it uses a control or comparison group to support or refute an inference.

By definition, a case control study involves two populations — cases and controls. In case control studies, the unit is the individual rather than the group. The focus is on a disease or some other health problem that has already developed.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 87.

questions.text: These are all continuous variables, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Blood Groups A, B, ABO are not an example of continuous variables. They are examples of discrete variables. 

  • A quantitative variable may be continuous or discrete if they are typically obtained by measuring or counting, respectively.
  • If it can take on two particular real values such that it can also take on all real values between them, the variable is continuous in that interval.
  • Continuous variables may take any value (typically between certain limits).
  • Most biomedical variables are continuous (e.g., a patient’s weight, height, age, and blood pressure).
  • However, the process of measuring or reporting continuous variables will reduce them to a discrete variable; blood pressure may be reported to the nearest whole millimeter of mercury, weight to the nearest pound, and age to the nearest year.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 3.

questions.text: Which of the following is utilised to choose patients based on potential variables that will influence the outcomes?
questions.solution:
• Stratified random sampling involves dividing the population into subgroups (strata) based on specific characteristics or variables that are expected to influence the outcomes (e.g., age, gender, socioeconomic status). Then, random samples are taken from each stratum. This method ensures that each subgroup is appropriately represented in the final sample, which helps in making more accurate inferences about the entire population.
 
  • Systematic random sampling: This method involves selecting every nth individual from a list after a random starting point. It does not specifically consider the influence of variables on outcomes.
 
  • Simple random sampling: In this method, every individual in the population has an equal chance of being selected. It does not account for any specific variables that might affect outcomes.
 
  • Cluster sampling: This involves dividing the population into clusters (usually based on geography or other natural groupings), then randomly selecting some clusters and including all individuals within those clusters in the sample. It is used mainly for practical reasons when a population is spread out, but it does not specifically address variables influencing outcomes.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 913.

questions.text: Which of these metrics is used in anganwadi centres to track children's growth?
questions.solution:
• Growth charts used in India at Aanganwadi centres are based on weight on age parameters.
 
  • The growth chart shows
  1. normal zone of weight for age,
  2. undernutrition (below-2 SD) and
  3. severely underweight zone (below-3 SD).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 622.

questions.text: Despite the fact that there is a difference, a study cannot find a meaningful correlation between two variables. What kind of error is this?
questions.solution:
• A type II error, also known as an error of the second kind, occurs when the null hypothesis is false, but erroneously fails to be rejected. It is failing to assert what is present, a miss.
 
  • A type I error, also known as an error of the first kind, occurs when the null hypothesis (H0) is true, but is rejected. It is asserting something that is absent, a false hit.



Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 28.

questions.text: The following criteria are used to determine how strongly a risk factor is linked to a disease:
questions.solution:
Strength of association  in epidemiological studies refers to the degree to which an exposure (like a risk factor) is linked to an outcome (like a disease).

  • It is measured by relative risk (RR) in Cohort studies and Odds ratio in Case control studies.

 Cohort study: The strength of association is often expressed using relative risk (RR), which compares the incidence of the outcome in the exposed group to the incidence in the unexposed group.

  • RR = I (exposed) / I (non-exposed)


Case control study : The strength of association is typically measured using odds ratio (OR), which compares the odds of exposure in cases to the odds of exposure in controls.
 
  • Interpretation: An OR greater than 1 suggests a positive association, while an OR less than 1 suggests a negative association. Like RR, the distance from 1 indicates the strength of the association.
 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 81.

choices.text: Given data inadequate for calculation of class intervals

questions.text: What will the 95% confidence interval (CI) be given a sample size of 100 and an estimated prevalence of 10%?
questions.solution:
A confidence interval indicates where the population parameter is likely to reside.
  • For example, a 95% confidence interval of the mean [9 11] suggests you can be 95% confident that the population mean is between 9 and 11.
  • Confidence intervals also help you navigate the uncertainty of how well a sample estimates a value for an entire population.


95% CI= P+_ 2SE (proportion)
= 10+_ 2 square under root of 900/100
= 10 +_ 2 * 3 = 4-16


So, (2) option is correct.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 11.

choices.text: Incidence decreases when a program is effective
Vaccination strategies decrease the incidence of a disease
Newer and more effective treatment modalities decrease the incidence
Incidence implies the number of new cases detected over a fixed time

questions.text: Pick the statement that is untrue about 'incidence'.
questions.solution:
Newer and more effective treatment modalities do not decrease the incidence. Incidence is a measure of the probability of occurrence of a given medical condition in a population within a specified period of time. Effective treatment modalities can decrease the prevalence of a disease, not the incidence of that disease.

Incidence rate is defined as “the number of NEW cases occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time”. 

This suggests even if newer and more effective modalities occur, new cases are bound to occur.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 68.

questions.text: In a hospital, 30 children's APGAR scores were collected, and the majority of the values were 7 or higher. What conclusions can you draw from this data distribution?
questions.solution:
Since, more number of children have a higher APGAR score, the tail of the distribution curve will be towards the left.
Hence, the data will be negatively skewed.

1)Negative skew: The left tail is longer; the mass of the distribution is concentrated on the right of the figure.
  • The distribution is said to be left-skewed or skewed to the left.
  • Negative Skew: Mode> Median> Mean

2)Positive skew: The right tail is longer; the mass of the distribution is concentrated on the left of the figure.
  • The distribution is said to be right-skewed or skewed to the right.  
  • Positive Skew: Mode < Median < Mean

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 8.

questions.text: You have been asked to create a study for a condition with a 10% population prevalence. 5% alpha error must be maintained with 20% relative precision and 20% power. How many people will actually be included in the study's sample?
questions.solution:
Sample size is calculated with the help of formula:

N = (Z^2 )* p (1-p) / d2

Where,
N = sample size
Z = 1.96 for 95% confidence (alpha error = 5% means 95% CI)
p = Estimated population prevalence (10%)
d = Acceptable relative precision (20%)

N = [(1.96)^2]× 0.10 × 0.90 / [(10/100*20/100)^2]
     = 864

So, option B (900) will be correct answer.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 22.

choices.text: No breath-holding is required for the procedure
Platelet count of less than 40,000 is a contraindication
It is useful is diagnosis of infiltrative and granulomatous disorders
It can be done in both prone and lateral positions

questions.text: Which of these is not true about the procedure in which this needle is used?
questions.solution:
• This is Bone marrow aspiration needle / Jamshedi's needle. So, PC < 40k is not a contraindication for this procedure. All other options are correct about BMA.
  • Absolute contraindications to bone marrow biopsy and aspiration include severe bleeding diatheses such as severe hemophilia or severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy.
  • Thrombocytopenia is not a contraindication, and platelet transfusion can be performed if clinically warranted prior to the procedure, commonly performed if platelet counts are below 20,000 cells/microliter.
  • Thrombocytopenia is rather in indication for performing bone marrow biopsy. *  CONTRAINDICATIONS FOR BM BIOPSY:
  • Hemorrhagic disorders such DIC, concurrent anticoagulant usage, and congenital coagulation factor deficits (such as hemophilia).
  • The most frequent and dangerous occurrence is bleeding, especially in thrombocytopenic patients and those taking aspirin, warfarin, or heparin.
  • In these patients, a BMA or BMTB should only be performed if it is absolutely necessary. If this is the case, factor replacement or stopping anticoagulation should be considered before the surgery, and the patient should be thoroughly watched for 24 hours afterward. BMA is not contraindicated in cases of severe thrombocytopenia as long as the site is kept under pressure for an extended period of time to stop bleeding.
  •  When a bone marrow biopsy is recommended for obese individuals with severe thrombocytopenia, it is better to administer a platelet transfusion to increase the platelet count to > 15 x 10^9/L.
  • Other potential issues include persistent discomfort, a fracture (related to osteoporosis), and damage to nearby structures (such as damage to arteries).
  • At the sampling site, there may be skin infections or recent radiation therapy.
Reference: 
Rindy LJ, Chambers AR. Bone Marrow Aspiration and Biopsy. [Updated 2023 May 29]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559232/

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic man with palpitations arrives at the AIIMS emergency department. Systolic blood pressure was 70 mm Hg at the time of assessment. His ECG was recorded in an emergency and is shown below. What is the management's next most important step?
questions.solution:
• The ECG is showing narrow complex tachycardia with absent P-waves with regular R-R interval. The patient is likely to be having paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).
 
  • Since the patient is in shock with hypotension, electrical cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.
 
  • Drug of choice for PSVT is Adenosine but it is to be used in hemodynamically stable patients.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1898, 1899.

questions.text: A 76-year-old male patient who has been experiencing retrosternal chest pain for six hours comes to the AIIMS emergency room. The next EKG was recorded. What is going to be your main line of management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows STEMI and onset of symptom is 6 hours so PCI is the best possible intervention.
PCI could be done upto 24 hours. Ideal door to balloon time is 90 minutes.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2058, 2059.

  2. Aortic regurgitation with aortic stenosis (AR+AS)
  3. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

questions.text: When patients are being monitored daily, the tourniquet test is utilised for:
questions.solution:
• The tourniquet test (TT) is a physical examination technique that can identify and stratify dengue disease.
  • Infection with DENV may result in increased capillary permeability, a physiological state that the TT exploits by applying sustained pressure to these small vessels.
  • Positive tourniquet test with greater than 10 petechiae per one square inch.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1640, 1641.

questions.text: Which of the following should be monitored the most closely in a person with dengue hemorrhagic fever?
questions.solution:
• Thrombocytopenia can be seen in Dengue as well.
  • Diagnosis of DHF needs the presence of Rise in Hematocrit of 20% or more i.e. Hemoconcentration.
  • Despite the name, the critical feature that distinguishes DHF from dengue fever is not haemorrhage , but rather plasma leakage resulting from increased vascular permeability.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1643.

questions.text: Which of the following will you hear on auscultation in a patient with post-tuberculosis bronchiectasis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Both early and late inspiratory crackles
 
  • Post-tuberculous bronchiectasis typically only affects one lung and causes coarse, biphasic crackles.
  • It is typical to hear late inspiratory fine crackles in people with CHF, COPD, or pneumonia.
  • As a result of pulmonary edema, bibasilar crepitations are heard (indicative of fluid overload).
  • There is a sound of tubular breathing during a consolidation.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2174.

questions.text: An individual with probable TB has had a pleural tap. All of the following tests should be done on the pleural fluid, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
• The most important diagnostic tests in pleural fluid specimen in a patient with suspected TB are GeneXpert (PCR) and ADA levels.
 
  • Total Protein levels and LDH levels are required to differentiate between Transudative and Exudative effusion according to Light's Criteria. So doing a pleural fluid Albumin level separately will not be very useful. Total protein estimation should be done instead.
 
  • The pleural fluid is an exudate with predominantly small lymphocytes. The diagnosis is established by demonstrating high levels of TB markers in the pleural fluid (adenosine deaminase >40 IU/L or interferon γ >140 pg/mL). CBNAAT or Gene Xpert is the diagnostic investigation of choice in TB pleural effusion. Alternatively, the diagnosis can be established by culture of the pleural fluid, needle biopsy of the pleura, or thoracoscopy.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1368, 2198, 2199.

She has a BP of 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate of 115 per minute and sinus tachycardia on ECG. choices.text: Patient should be asked to take normal breaths
The cuff pressure should be increased to 20 mm over systolic pressure
The cuff should be slowly deflated until the first Korotkoff sound is heard only during expiration

questions.text: A patient with possible cardiac tamponade arrives at the emergency department of the AIIMS. All of the following measures should be observed while taking BP EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The cuff is slowly deflated and the paradoxical pulse is recorded from the point when first Korotkoff sound is heard only during expiration to when it is heard in both expiration and inspiration. Rest statements are true.
 
  • Pulsus paradoxus refers to a fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration. Pulsus paradoxus is measured by noting the difference between the systolic pressure at which the Korotkoff sounds are first heard (during expiration) and the systolic pressure at which the Korotkoff sounds are heard with each heartbeat, independent of the respiratory phase.
 
  • Between these two pressures, the Korotkoff sounds are heard only intermittently and during expiration. The cuff pressure must be decreased slowly to appreciate the finding.
 
  • The patient must also breathe normally during the recording.

Pulsus paradoxus is seen in patients with:
 
  1. Pericardial tamponade
  2. Massive pulmonary embolism
  3. Hemorrhagic shock
  4. Severe obstructive lung disease
  5. Tension pneumothorax.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1818.

choices.text: 8 mg/dL (direct = 18.6 mg/dL) in the serum, respectively. What plausible diagnosis is there?

Fulminant hepatitis due to hepatitis B infection

questions.text:
A pregnant woman of 27 years old arrives with severe jaundice and decreased sensory function. The patient is found to be severely icteric, unresponsive to orders, and the pelvic ultrasound shows an intrauterine foetal demise. The values of AST and ALT are 1063 and 28.8 mg/dL (direct = 18.6 mg/dL) in the serum, respectively. What plausible diagnosis is there? 
Viral indicators are: 
Anti-HAV lgG Reactive
Anti-HAV lgM Nonreactive
HbSAg Nonreactive
Anti-HbSAg Nonreactive
Anti-HBc lgM Nonreactive
Anti-HBc lgG Reactive
Anti-HCV lgG Nonreactive
Anti-HEV lgM Reactive
Anti-HEV lgG Nonreactive
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Fulminant hepatitis due to hepatitis E infection.
 
  • From the markers mentioned, it can be concluded that the patient is previously infected and immune to hepatitis A and hepatitis B. Since the IgM for hepatitis E is positive, the patient is suffering from Acute fulminant hepatitis E. This is common in pregnant women.
 
  • Hepatitis E causes fatal fulminant hepatitis in upto 20% cases in pregnant women.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2574, 2578.

questions.text: An individual with spread cancer visits the palliative care clinic complaining of nausea, vomiting, and impaired sensory perception. Investigations reveal hypercalcemia. What will be the initial chain of command?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Intravenous fluids
 
  • Hypercalcemia is a sign of paraneoplastic syndromes which arise due to several types of cancers in the body.
  • Intravenous fluids will increase blood volume thereby reducing the concentration of blood calcium levels.
  • Hence it is the first step, after that IV bisphosphonates can be given. Hence correct option is 3.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1058.

choices.text: Non-invasive ventilation with continuous positive airway pressure

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with bronchial asthma who has been previously diagnosed presented to the emergency department of AIIMS complaining of severe dyspnea, diaphoresis, and wheezing. Upon examination, you discover that the patient is aware and has a heart rate of 144 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 96/64 mm Hg. A blood gas examination of the arterial circulation revealed a pH of 7.3, pO2 of 50 mm Hg, and pCO2 of 70 mm Hg. patient shows no improvement on O2 therapy with nasal prongs. What should be the next line of management ?
questions.solution:
Non-invasive ventilation with continuous positive airway pressure should be followed next in managing Acute exacerbation of Asthma not improving on conventional O2 therapy.
  • The patient here has respiratory acidosis with elevated PaCO2. So, the best management strategy for these patients is assisted ventilation with CPAP to promote CO2 washout and correct acidosis.
  • Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are employed when other less invasive maneuvers have failed.
 
  • Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation to assist with respiratory exhaustion is used to prevent a need for intubation, and helium-oxygen mixtures may be used to decrease the work of breathing.
  • Mechanical ventilation may be difficult in patients with status asthmaticus due to high positive pressures in the setting of high resistance to airflow due to airway obstruction. Most patients with asthma attacks present with hypocapnia due to a high respiratory rate. Normal or near-normal PaCO2 in a patient with asthma in respiratory distress should raise concerns of impending respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2158.

questions.text: A glass factory worker presented with complaints of numbness in hands and feet, generalized weakness and constipation. Radiograph showed linear lines on metaphyses of knee and wrist joints. How will you diagnose this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features are suggestive of exposure to lead. 

Main causes for the pathology of lead is that it interferes with the activity of an essential enzyme called Delta aminolevulinic acid dehydratase, which is important in the biosynthesis of heme, the cofactor found in hemoglobin.

  • Lead also inhibits the enzyme ferrochelatase, another enzyme involved in the formation of heme.
  • Ferrochelatase catalyzes the joining of protoporphyrin and Fe2+ plus to form heme.
  • Another effect of lead's interference with heme synthesis is the buildup of heme precursors, such as aminolevulinic acid, which may be directly or indirectly harmful to neurons and which are excreted in urine.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3580.

choices.text: Before performing the ABG, syringe should be loaded with 0.3 cc of heparin
A different site should be tried if modified Allen’s test is negative

questions.text: You are instructed to conduct an ABG on a patient by a second-year PG resident. All of the following regarding an ABG are true, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Before performing the ABG, syringe should be loaded with 0.3 cc of heparin.
Syringe should be flushed with heparin and not loaded.
 
  • Normal pH, HCO3, and PCO2 levels may not indicate absence of an acid-base imbalance: This statement is true. While normal values of pH, bicarbonate (HCO3), and partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) may suggest a balanced acid-base state, they do not guarantee the absence of an acid-base imbalance. There are different types of acid-base disorders, such as respiratory acidosis/alkalosis and metabolic acidosis/alkalosis, which can exist even with normal pH, HCO3, and PCO2 values. Additional parameters and the evaluation of compensatory mechanisms are required to make an accurate assessment of acid-base balance.
  • A different site should be tried if modified Allen's test is negative: This statement is true. The modified Allen's test is performed to assess collateral circulation in the hand before arterial puncture. If the modified Allen's test is negative (indicating inadequate collateral circulation), it is recommended to try a different arterial site for blood sampling to avoid potential complications, such as hand ischemia.
  • Radial artery is the preferred site: This statement is true. The radial artery is commonly preferred for arterial blood gas (ABG) sampling due to its accessibility and lower risk of complications compared to other sites. It is easily palpable and provides a relatively comfortable experience for patients.
ABG Steps-
    1. Heparin rinse
    2. Modified Allen’s test performed
    3. Wrist extension
    4. Needle pierced at 45 degrees angle




Reference: Trulock EP III. Arterial Blood Gases. In: Walker HK, Hall WD, Hurst JW, editors. Clinical Methods: The History, Physical, and Laboratory Examinations. 3rd edition. Boston: Butterworths; 1990. Chapter 49. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK371/

WHO Guidelines on Drawing Blood: Best Practices in Phlebotomy. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2010. Annex I, Modified Allen test. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK138652/

questions.text: A patient's laboratory tests revealed pH = 7.3, HCO3- = 15 meq/l and pCO2 = 35 mm Hg. What is the probable primary acid base imbalance?

Normal range: PH= 7.35-7.45 , pCO2= 40-44mmHg , HCO3=22-28mmol/ml.

Here it is a state of acidosis, with low bicarbonate and low pCO2 which means something in the metabolism was causing acidosis which is now being compensated by CO2 washout by the body via lungs. So, its Metabolic acidosis.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with abdominal pain, a binge drinking episode, shock, and a blood pressure of 70/50 mm Hg and a heart rate of 115 beats per minute arrives at the emergency room. The patient has an oxygen saturation level of 70 mm Hg. The amount of serum creatinine was 2.4 mg/dl and BUN 30 mg/dl. The patient's transaminases were elevated. Based on the CT scan below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Alcohol binge is a common cause of acute pancreatitis. Here the CT scan showing blurry margins of the pancreas is confirming the diagnosis.

Since vitals are unstable and end organ damage is developing as S. Cr is 2.4mg/dL and BUN is 30 mg/dl, therefore it is Severe Acute Pancreatitis. 

Markers for Severe acute Pancreatitis: 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2661.

choices.text: IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient is experiencing respiratory distress, nausea, vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain. His pulse rate was 115/min and his blood pressure was 90/60 mm Hg. The ER took the chest X-ray that is shown below. Which is the next best course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy

The given chest X-Ray shows gas under diaphragm suggestive of Hollow viscus perforation.
  • The immediate management in place should be IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy.
 
  • The immediate management should focus on stabilizing the patient's vital signs and treating the underlying infection. IV fluids and antibiotics can help to stabilize the patient's blood pressure and address the infection, till then the patient can be prepared for Laparotomy.
 
  • Emergency Laparotomy is necessary to identify and repair the site of perforation to prevent further complications and is the definite line of management.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 413, 414.

questions.text:
After a laparoscopic hernia operation, the attending surgeon requests that you use 3-0 nylon to stitch the skin wound. Which set of tools are the ones you should use for suturing?


1. 


2.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 

A basic suturing kit includes the following:

  • A needle holder.
  • Toothed forceps, with a hook to handle tissue.
  • Fine suturing scissors.
  • The appropriate suturing material.

It’s very important to consider the suturing material that is used when performing the operation. In turn, choosing the right suturing material is made easy by considering the location and tension of the wound. Other equally important factors to consider about are the tensile and knot strength, handling of the wound, and tissue reactivity.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 1150.

questions.text: You were contacted by a 56-year-old woman who had been diagnosed with breast cancer. The immunohistochemical staining of her tissue revealed the following. Her2 Neu is negative. What can you say about the patient's prognosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Poor prognosis
 
  • The IHC profile depicts a triple negative breast cancer, i.e. a Basal like profile as ER,PR and Her 2 are all negative.
  • Positive staining is seen as brownish dots over the slide.
  • These negative results mean that the growth of the cancer is not supported by the hormones estrogen and progesterone, nor by the presence of too many HER2 receptors.
  • Therefore, triple-negative breast cancer does not respond to hormonal therapy (such as tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors) or therapies that target HER2 receptors, such as Herceptin (trastuzumab). In general, survival rates tend to be lower with TNBC compared to other forms of breast cancer.

Fig: Molecular classification of breast cancer

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 931.

questions.text:
For a patient with breast cancer, a surgical attending has finished a modified radical mastectomy. Subcuticular sutures are required to be used to close the wound. Which suture will you pick from this list?
1. 

2.

4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 

Monocryl Sutures 3-0 or 4-0 with cutting needle are used in closure of MRM wounds by subcuticular suturing.
Option 2 showing Vicryl is showing round bodied needle , hence not correct.

* [Extra Edge]: Subcuticular suture
 
  • This technique is used in skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily. The suture material used may be either absorbable or non-absorbable. For non-absorbable sutures, the ends may be secured using a collar and bead, or tied loosely over the wound. When absorbable sutures are used, the ends may be secured using a buried knot.
  • Small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound and then gently pulled together, thus approximating the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.
  • Monocryl Sutures 3-0 or 4-0 with cutting needle are mostly used in Subcuticular suture technique.
     

Fig: Subcuticular suture technique

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 108.

questions.text: A 70 years old patient presents with a lesion on the cheek with raised, pearly borders and with telangiectasias on surface of the lesion. What is the likely diagnosis?

questions.text: The head, both upper limbs on each side, the front of the chest, and the abdomen are all burned in a two-year-old. How much body surface area is involved?
questions.solution:
To estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) burned in a two-year-old, the "Lund and Browder chart" is commonly used, which adjusts for age since children have different body proportions than adults.

For a two-year-old:

  • The head accounts for approximately 18% of the TBSA.
  • Each arm accounts for about 9% of the TBSA (total for both arms: 18%).
  • The front of the chest is about 9%, and the abdomen is about 9% (total for the front of the chest and abdomen: 18%).

Adding these together:

  • Head: 18%
  • Upper limbs (both): 18%
  • Front of the chest: 9%
  • Abdomen: 9%

Total: 18 + 18 + 9 + 9 = 54%

Therefore, the correct answer is 3. 54 %




Fig: Modified Lund and Browder table and diagram

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: The surgeon instructed the intern to remove the Foley's catheter following surgery, but the intern was unable to do so. In spite of his best efforts, the surgeon was unable to remove the Foley's catheter. What action is necessary now?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Use ultrasound guidance to locate and prick the balloon and then remove the catheter
 
  • When unable to remove a Foley's catheter, the next step would be to use ultrasound guidance to locate and puncture the balloon, allowing for deflation and subsequent removal of the catheter.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best approach of lowering intracranial pressure in a 40-year-old patient with a head injury?

questions.text: Which of these do not increase at full term in pregnancy?

  • Inspiratory reserve volume Maximum volume of air that can be inspired at the end of a normal inspiration
  • No change Expiratory reserve volume Maximum volume of air that can be expired at the end of a normal expiration ↓ (15-20%) Inspiratory capacity Maximum volume of air that can be inspired at the end of a normal expiration ↑ (5-10%) Vital capacity Maximum volume of air that can be forcibly expired after a maximal inspiration

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman visits your clinic to have her infertility evaluated. Asherman's syndrome can be seen on a hysterosalpingogram. What signs will the patient experience?
questions.solution:
• In Ashermann syndrome, Intrauterine adhesions cause total or partial obliteration of the endocervix and/or uterine cavity, resulting in hypomenorrhea or amenorrhea, infertility, and pregnancy loss.
     
  • Scar tissue builds up inside the uterus and/or cervix, causing Asherman syndrome (intrauterine adhesions or synechiae). The infective causes of these adhesions are schistosomiasis and TB, with dilatation and curettage(Most common), and uterine surgery being other causes.
Clinical Features are
1. Infertility
2.Amennorrhea
3. Hypomenorrhea

choices.text: Observation and follow-up for cyst after 2–3 months

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is experiencing some lower abdominal ache. She previously underwent two normal full-term deliveries. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks back. A palpable lump in the adnexa is discovered during a pelvic exam. You discover a 5 cm ovarian cyst on the USG pelvis. What ought you do next?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Observation and follow-up for cyst after 2–3 months.
Since her last period was 3 weeks ago, it could be a luteal cyst which is large and hence symptomatic. The pain could be most likely due to ovulation.

Management of Simple cyst: 
 
  • A simple cyst <7 cm, unilocular, echo free without solid areas or papillary projections, with normal serum cancer antigen (CA 125) should be followed up with repeat ultrasound (endovaginal) in 3–6 months time.
  • COCs suppresses the levels of gonadotropins. Thereby COCs reduces the stimulatory effects on the ovaries and the cysts. Low vascular resistance on color flow Doppler study suggests malignancy whereas high resistance usually suggests normal or benign disease. A cyst in a perimenopausal or postmenopausal women should be removed when CA 125 is abnormal (>35 IU/mL) or the cyst is persistently large (>10 cm).
  • Removal (cystectomy) may be done by laparotomy or laparoscopy.
Adnexal Mass of ovary in  reproductive age-
3-5cm- wait and watch
5-7 cm- Follow up with USG
>= 7cm- Surgery 


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 452-457.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman who is pregnant with her third child delivers a healthy baby and an unharmed placenta. After giving birth, the woman experiences acute vaginal bleeding 30 minutes later. Sonogram on the table showed retained placental tissue. What kind of placenta is believed to be present?
questions.solution:
Placenta succenturiata
  
  • Membranous placenta – This is where the placenta is thin and covers a large part of the fetal membranes, but it doesn’t typically cause retained tissue.
  • Placenta fenestrae – A rare anomaly where there are areas of the placenta without villi. It does not typically lead to retained tissue.
  • Placenta accreta – This occurs when the placenta abnormally attaches too deeply into the uterine wall, but it generally causes difficulty in delivering the placenta and often requires surgical removal, rather than presenting as retained tissue seen later

questions.text: A G3P2 who is 30 years old and has amenorrhea for 10 weeks has an intrauterine pregnancy with an intrauterine contraceptive device in place. The IUCD string was discernible at the cervical os during a pelvic exam. The patient wants to carry out the pregnancy. How will you proceed?
questions.solution:

  • One in three patients with adenomyosis is asymptomatic, but the rest may present with heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, or infertility.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy complains of right shoulder and neck ache with limited range of motion. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
• Klippel Feil Syndrome is characterized by congenital fusion of at least two cervical vertebrae with an absence of the intervertebral discs.
  • The classical triad consists of a short neck, limitation of head and neck movements and a low posterior hairline.
  • This triad is present in 50% of patients Klippel-Feil can be associated with multiple anomalies such as congenital heart defects, deafness as well as other skeletal deformities such as scoliosis, malformed ribs and sprengel deformity. 
  • The given image shows Sprengel deformity of left side as the scapula is located at a higher level due to a persistent omovertebral bar. This causes limitation of scapular movement and glenohumeral joint.

questions.text:
A mother who has a baby who is three months old asks the doctor if she can give her infant food(cereal).
What issues/future problems might this result in her child if she feeds cereal instead of breast milk?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is (1) Allergy due to the food content.

UNICEF, the World Health Organisation, and the Indian Academy of Pediatrics recommend that babies receive only breast milk for the first 6 months of life.

The most important basis/reason for this recommendation is allergy due to the proteins in animal milk and infant formula milk. Exclusive breastfeeding is associated with a lower risk of asthma, eczema, other allergic disorders, Crohn's and ulcerative colitis, obesity, leukaemia, diarrhoea, etc.

Moreover sweet supplements may cause the baby to be more inclined to drink supplements rather than breast milk which is more nutritious and essential for the baby.

questions.text: A three month old newborn, who was healthy at birth develops chronic liver failure and muscle weakness. On examinations, serum glucose is low, associated with ketoacidosis and reduced pH. The ALT and AST levels rise. Uric acid and lactate levels in the blood are normal. When administered intravenously, glucagon elevates blood sugar levels after meals but not after an overnight fast. Liver biopsy shows increased glycogen in liver. Which enzyme in this youngster is most likely to be defective?
questions.solution:
In this child, a combination of liver and muscle involvement with ketoacidosis and raised liver enzymes in a setting of Hypoglycemia especially in fasting state, points towards Type III Glycogen Storage disease, i.e. Cori's disease caused by deficiency of Debranching enzyme. The liver Biopsy confirms diagnosis. The muscle weakness due to any other cause is ruled out by normal urate and lactate.
Type Name Deficient Enzyme Key Specific Features
Type I Von Gierke Disease Glucose-6-phosphatase Severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis
Type II Pompe Disease Lysosomal acid α-glucosidase Cardiomegaly, muscle weakness, "floppy baby" (infantile form)
Type III Cori Disease Debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase) Milder hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, accumulation of limit dextrin
Type IV Andersen Disease Branching enzyme Hepatosplenomegaly, liver cirrhosis, early death
Type V McArdle Disease Muscle glycogen phosphorylase Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria (red urine)
Type VI Hers Disease Liver glycogen phosphorylase Mild fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a persistent fever and signs of sepsis had a blood pressure reading of 90/60 mm Hg, a pulse rate of 144/min, and a respiration rate of 30/min. What is the preferred starting fluids for management?

questions.text: A 30 years old male presented with knew pain for the last 6 months.X-ray is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Xrays shows a circumscribed osteolytic bone tumour involving the epiphysis - the most likely diagnosis is Giant cell tumor.
  • Giant cell tumor is a benign bone tumor that typically affects young adults between the ages of 20 and 40 years old.
  • It is more common in women than in men and frequently occurs in the long bones, such as the femur or tibia.
  • The X-ray image shows a well-defined osteolytic lesion with a thin rim of sclerotic bone, which is a characteristic feature of giant cell tumors
Other options
  • Multiple myeloma- commonly seen in older age group atleast around 60 years of age.
  • Simple bone cyst will be a well defined radiolucent lesion commonly seen in bones of upper limb and in an age group of 10-20. It is characterized by a fluid-filled cavity within the bone
  • An adamantinoma is a rare low-grade malignant bone tumor typically found in the diaphyses of long bones in 20-40 year olds.

questions.text: Which of the following causes an infection that results in a fungal-like lesion on the cornea?
questions.solution:
• Nocardia asteroides, a filamentous bacterium, causes keratitis that resembles corneal ulcers caused by fungus. The ulcer presents with a filamen­tous appearing border and satellite lesions.
  • Nocardia is a Gram-positive, filamentous bacteria. Nocardia is obligatorily aerobic and variably acid-fast. On Gram staining, the filaments of these organisms are seen as branching and intertwined; some might display terminal clubs, and the filaments often fragment into bacillary and coccoid forms.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man arrived with right eye pain and watering that had been present for 36 hours. A 3 x 2 cm corneal ulcer measuring raised borders, fluffy hyphae, finger-like projections, and minor hypopyon in the cornea is discovered during examination. What's the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
• Pain and watering in the eye for 36 hours with presence of corneal ulcer having elevated margins, feathery hyphae, finger-like projections and minimal hypopyon is highly suggestive of fungal corneal ulcer.
 
  • Among the options, Aspergillus is the only fungus.
 
  • Fungal corneal ulcers are commonly caused due to injury by vegetative material. These ulcers have feathery borders. Along with this, satellite lesions, ciliary congestion and a Wessely immune ring can be seen around the ulcer.
 


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 227.
