questions.text: Phenol red thread test is used for dry eye:
questions.solution:
For Phenol red test, autoclaved, 75-mm-long phenol-red impregnated thread with 3-mm bent end was placed in lower fornix for 15 seconds. When the phenol red comes in contact with alkaline tears, it changes color from white to yellow-orange, yellow and then to red.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 279.

questions.text: What is the color of the lesion immediately after photodynamic therapy?
questions.solution:
Option is 1: Unchanged After treating an area with photodynamic therapy, that area of the skin would be usually red, indicating normal erythema, and may appear to be flaking or peeling, as it would after a mild sunburn. Therefore, the color of the lesion would be unchanged or red. The redness, and perhaps some of the flaking, can last for several days to a week or even two weeks. (After that, skin returns to normal.)

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 22.3

questions.text: When reading the Snellen chart from a distance of 6 metres, what angle does the largest letter subtend on the reader's eye?
questions.solution:
For the 6/6 letter, the m inimum angle of resolution is 5 mins of arc [( 5min of arc) X 6/6 = 5mins of arc]. The largest letter on the Snellen's chart subtends an angle of 50 minutes in the eye when viewed from a distance of 6 metres i.e 60/6 x 5mins of arc = 50 mins of arc.


Reference: Parson’s diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 87.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of nasal discharge, stuffiness, congestion, and anosmia. The woman also suffers from Asthma. The results of a para-nasal sinus CT scan are displayed below. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The correct option and the most likely diagnosis is option (3) Allergic Fungal Sinusitis (AFS).

This condition often affects individuals with asthma or a history of allergies. It is characterized by the presence of fungal material in the sinuses. The fungal elements can lead to chronic inflammation, and patients often present with nasal congestion, discharge, and anosmia, which matches the symptoms described.

On imaging, sinuses show complete opacification. Non contrast enhanced CT, the sinuses are opacified by centrally hyperdense material and have outer peripheral rim of hypodense mucosa. Thinning and sometimes erosion of sinus wall is also seen. 


Reference: P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 504

questions.text:
What is the encircled structure in the middle-ear cavity called ?


1`. Fossa incudis
2. Sinus tympani
3. Facial recess
4. Pyramidal fossa
questions.solution:
The sinus tympani (ST) is a critical anatomic region of the temporal bone. It lies medial to the facial nerve, between the ponticulus and the subiculum. This is the most common and constant depression present in the retrotympanic area. It is the most inaccessible site in the middle ear and mastoid. Cholesteatoma which has extended upto it is very difficult to eradicate.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 7

questions.text: A 5 years old child presents with voice change and stridor. Identify the abnormality marked on the fiberoptic laryngoscopy:
questions.solution:
Respiratory papillomatosis is a recurrent condition, common in children and presents with respiratory polyps. Respiratory papillomas are caused by the human papilloma virus (HPV). JORRP (Juvenile-onset) is more common and more severe than AORRP (Adult onset). JORRP is caused by exposure to HPV during the peripartum period. They're usually benign (non-cancerous). These growths can lead to vocal cord damage and airway problems. Because the virus is in the tissue, respiratory papillomas tend to reoccur even after they are removed. Treatment is laser resection of tumours.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 346

questions.text: A patient complained of diminished hearing in the right ear. Interpret the audiometric trace that follows:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Conductive hearing loss of right ear Conductive hearing loss of the right ear Increased air bone conduction gap confirms the conductive deafness. There is no Air bone conduction gap in sensorineural hearing loss.
 

  • This patient is showing improved hearing in left hear with constant difference in air and bone conduction,
  • I.e. decreased air conduction with normal bone conduction.
  • This is seen typically in conductive hearing loss.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 25

questions.text: Which of the following is a 'cold' method of tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
Microdebrider is a 'cold' method for tonsillectomy, while rest are considered 'hot' methods

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 489

questions.text: A 5 years old girl presented with lesion on the face for the last 3 months. A skin biopsy was performed and the findings are shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The biopsy is showing Molluscum Bodies seen typically in Molluscum contagiosum.
  • This disease is usually seen in young children (like in this case) and causes lesions on the face which are pearly white papules.
  • There may be a history of transmission from mother as well.
  • Also called as HP Bodies( Henderson-Paterson bodies ), these are intracytoplasmic, eosinophilic, granular inclusions within the keratinocytes of the basal, spinous, and granular layers of the epidermis.



Reference : Rook’s tex ok no Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume 2 Chapter 25 fig25.12

questions.text: A 35-year-old man complains about being bald. Examination revealed distinct bald areas without any scars. Small broken hairs were detected in the surrounding area. What is the plausible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Alopecia areata
  • Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease causing non-scarring hair loss. It is characterized by a circumscribed, smooth patch of hair loss.
  • Exclamation mark hairs are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease.
  • Alopecia areata preferentially targets pigmented hair. Older patients with grey hair have a mixture of white and pigmented hair.
  • If the disease progresses rapidly, only pigmented hair will be affected, sparing the white hair. This leads to a dramatic change in overall hair color that is called going white overnight.
  • Other options:
  • Telogen effluvium leads to diffuse hair loss that affects all hair equally, not just pigmented hair. So, overall hair color will not be affected.
  • Androgenetic alopecia is a disorder characterized by a reduction of hair fiber production by follicles and miniaturization. It is of two types , male pattern and female pattern hair loss. Male pattern hair loss may occur in female & vice versa is also true. Male pattern hair loss causes frontal hairline recession and thinning of the vertex.
  • Alopecia after chemotherapy is known as anagen effluvium. Hair loss following chemotherapy usually occurs within 1–3 weeks after initiation of the therapy. In this type of hair loss, the anagen phase is abruptly terminated. This leads to the loss of dystrophic or broken hairs and the condition is called anagen effluvium.

Reference:Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 89.31

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for erythrodermic psoriasis?
questions.solution:
• Methotrexate is the drug of choice for management of Erythrodermic Psoriasis.
  • Cyclosporine is also used for fast remission and later for maintenance methotrexate is used. 
  • Topical applications are adequate only for Psoriasis Vulgaris, not for the systemic variants.
  • The only indication of Oral steroids in Psoriasis is Pustular psoriasis of pregnancy.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 35.26

questions.text: A 45 years old male presents with itchy papules over face, neck and V area of chest for the last three years, which are exacerbated in summers and improved in winters. What test will you do to confirm diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 1: Patch test The given history points towards photoallergic contact dermatitis and is a delayed-type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
  • The dermatitis is localized to exposed areas of the skin, usually with welldemarcated margins where the skin is covered by clothing, for example at the collar and ‘V’ of the neck, below the end of sleeves on the backs of the hands, and on the ankles below the trouser legs.
  • Photopatch test: The main clinical indication includes the investigation of patients with eczematous rashes predominantly affecting lightexposed sites and a history of worsening following sun exposure.
Below is an image of Patch Test


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 39.5

questions.text:
An industrial worker presents to you with groin plaques that are scaly, annular, and irritating. The pruritus is reduced after applying corticosteroid ointment, however, the lesion's peripheral extension persisted and worsens.
What is the plausible diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• The above lesions/history is suggestive of Tinea cruris(crotch itch) which is a dermatophyte fungal infection of the groin region.
  • Caused usually by Trichophyton rubrum. The clinical picture includes Itching or a burning sensation in the groin area, thigh skin folds or anus, and scaly/annular lesions.
  • Steroids being anti-inflammatory initially decrease the acute inflammation and hence the pruritis/itching but they can also make antifungal medications less effective and the primary infection worse. (Reason why peripheral extension persisted and then worsened)




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.46, 32.47

questions.text: A 45 years old patient presented with multiple hypoaesthetic patches over trunk and extremities. On examination, ulnar and lateral popliteal nerves are enlarged bilaterally. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient here has multiple hypo-esthetic patches (seen in border­line leprosy) and bilateral symmetrical nerve thickening (suggestive of Lepromatous leprosy).
  • Now in lepromatous leprosy(LL), there is normal anesthesia. Hence, the patient fits in the category of Borderline Lepro­matous Leprosy(BL).





Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.8

questions.text: A 24 years old female presented with complaints of rash on exposure to sun, after exercise, when she gets angry or on eating spicy food. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Itching, burning, tingling, warmth, or irritation precedes the onset of numerous small (1-4 mm in diameter), pruritic wheals with large, surrounding flares is suggestive of Cholinergic urticaria.
  • This condition is caused by an increase in body temperature, which leads to the release of histamine from mast cells in the skin.
  • Exercise is the most common precipitating event for cholinergic urticaria, but any stimulus that causes sweating, including elevated environmental temperature, hot food, sauna baths, immersion in hot water, gustatory stimuli, emotional stress, and hemodialysis, can bring on an urticaria.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 42.11

questions.text: Pick the drug that undergoes Hoffman elimination.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Atracurium

Atracurium is rapidly eliminated by Hoffman elimination and thus can be given in a patient with liver or kidney dysfunction.

* [Extra Edge]: Hofmann elimination

  • This refers to inactivation of the drug in the body fluids by spon­taneous molecular rearrangement without the agency of any enzyme.
  • Atracurium’s disappearance from the body depends on hydrolysis of the ester moiety by plasma esterases and by a spontaneous or Hofmann degradation (cleavage of the N-alkyl portion in the benzylisoquinoline). Hence, two routes for termination of effect are available, both of which remain functional in renal failure.
     
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 32.

questions.text: Which drug does not act on neuromuscular junction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dantrolene

  • Dantrolene sodium is a postsynaptic muscle relaxant that lessens exci­tation-contraction coupling in muscle cells. It achieves this by inhibiting Ca ions release from sarcoplasmic reticulum stores by antagonizing ryanodine receptors. Hence, it is direct acting on muscle cells rather then the NMJ.
  • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant and mivacurium and pancuronium are non-depolarizing muscle relaxant, they at in NMJ.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 382.

choices.text: Level of needle insertion should be L1-L2 vertebral junction
The bevel end of needle should face up
Needle should be inserted in a slightly cephalad direction
Legs should be straightened for CSF pressure measurement

questions.text: Which of these is not true about lumbar puncture?
questions.solution:
• LP in adults is done at the level of L3-L4 because spinal cord ends at a level above that.
  • This is followed so that the Spinal cord is not injured during Puncture with LP needle. Rest all other options are correct.
 
  • The midline approach relies on the ability of patients and assistants to minimize lumbar lordosis and allow access to the subarachnoid space between adjacent spinous processes, usually at the L2-L3, L3-L4, or the L4-L5 space.
  • The spinal cord ends at the level of L1-L2 and so needle insertion above this level should be avoided.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1428,1429.

questions.text: The dosage of an anaesthetic can be precisely administered using a sevoflurane vaporizer. Which of the following attributes does it share with it?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Vapor pressure
 
  • Vapour pressure is a measure of the tendency of a material to change into the gaseous or vapour state, and it increases with temperature.
  • Clinically useful concentrations of sevoflurane can be achieved with the administration of sevoflurane through a vaporizer. 
  • In the case of a sevoflurane vaporizer, the vapor pressure of sevoflurane determines the concentration of the anesthetic delivered to the patient.
  • The other options, molecular weight, oil gas partition coefficient, and blood gas partition coefficient, are also important properties of anesthetics, but they do not directly relate to the precise administration of the anesthetic using a vaporizer.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 585, 586.

choices.text: Inducing agent and neuromuscular relaxant are administered subsequently
The patient is pre-oxygenated for 3 minutes before the procedure
Cricoid pressure has to be applied till the endotracheal tube has been secured with a cuff
Induction should be done with thiopentone sodium and succinylcholine for muscle relaxation

questions.text: Which of these is not true about rapid sequence induction done in a cardiac patient in emergency?
questions.solution:
• The given patient has a cardiac condition and hence Thiopentone induction is contraindicated in cardiac condition and hence cannot be used
  • Etomidate is the preferred induction agent in such a patient with history of cardiac disease
  • Etomidate is the most cardiostable inducing agent
Rapid Sequence Intubation done in cases of- 
Increased Gastric regurgitation chances- 
1. Pregnancy
2. Full stomach
3. Obstruction  

The following conditions should be considered a contraindication for the use of IV barbiturates(Thiopentone):
  1. when there is respiratory obstruction or an inadequate airway, thiopental may worsen respiratory depression
  2. severe cardiovascular instability or shock contraindicate its use
  3. status asthmaticus is a condition in which airway control and ventilation may be worsened further by thiopental
  4. porphyria may be precipitated or acute attacks may be accentuated by the administration of thiopental
  5. without proper induction equipment (IV instrumentation) and airway equipment (means of artificial ventilation), thiopental should not be administered.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 653, 668, 1382, 1383.

questions.text: What is correct sequence of age and MAC?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Infants>Neonates>Adults
 
  • MAC, the minimum alveolar concentration at 1 atmosphere that prevents movement in 50% of patients exposed to a surgical incision.
  • It decreases with age after 1 year.
  • It is lesser in neonates followed by increase upto 1 year of age and then gradual decline to values lesser then those in neonates.
  • Infants have a higher MAC than that of older children or adults.





Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2428, 2429.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of anaphylaxis in the immediate perioperative period?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of perioperative anaphylaxis are Antibiotics and Muscle relaxants followed by opioids and intravenous anesthesia.
  •  Induction agents causing anaphylaxis is rare.
  • In the older French study (2004), the most common causes were neuromuscular blocking agents (58%), latex (20%), and antibiotics (13%). Conversely, in the more recent United Kingdom study (2016), the most common precipitating agents were antibiotics (53%), neuromuscular blocking agents (33%), and chlorhexidine (9%). 
  • In this question, since Antibiotics is not in option so preferred answer should be Muscle relaxants.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 980.

choices.text: Block of Cardio-accelerator fibers of synthetic origin

questions.text: The anesthetist used high doses of bupivacaine to do a subarachnoid block on a 46-year-old male patient. He was discovered to have 72/44 mm Hg blood pressure and a 52/min heart rate after 10 minutes. The block's level was confirmed to be T6 upon inspection. What is the likely cause of the bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Reverse Bainbridge reflex
  • The Bezold–Jarisch reflex involves a variety of cardiovascular and neurological processes which cause hypopnea, hypotension and bradycardia in response to noxious stimuli detected in the cardiac ventricles. following i.v. injection of Capsaicin, Veratridine, 5HT etc. Similar to J-Reflex in lungs by J Receptors.
  • The Bainbridge reflex or Bainbridge effect (also called the atrial reflex) is a cardiovascular reflex causing an increase in heart rate in response to increased stretching of the wall of the right atrium due to increased filling of the right atrium with venous blood.
  • A “reverse” Bainbridge reflex has been proposed to explain the decreases in heart rate observed under conditions in which venous return is reduced, such as during spinal and epidural anesthesia, controlled hypotension, and severe hemorrhage.
Online Reference: 
Crystal, George J. PhD, FAHA; Salem, M. Ramez MD. The Bainbridge and the “Reverse” Bainbridge Reflexes: History, Physiology, and Clinical Relevance. Anesthesia & Analgesia 114(3):p 520-532, March 2012. | DOI: 10.1213/ANE.0b013e3182312e21

questions.text: External beam radiation of the entire pelvis was used to treat a patient with endometrial cancer. Which of the following organs is radiosensitive to the greatest extent in the pelvic area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ovary

According to law of Bergonie and Tribondeau, radiosensitivity is directly proportional to mitosis and inversely proportional to differentiation.

The tolerance dose for Ovaries is the least.

  • Ovary= 2-3 Gy
  • Vagina= 90 Gy
  • Bladder = 65 Gy
  • Rectum= 60 Gy
Summary of radiosensitivity of various tissues: 



Remember- Most common organ affected due to radiation is skin. Among all the layers, Stratum basale is the most affected due to presence of actively dividing cells.


Reference: Perez & Brady's Principles and Practice of Radiation Oncology, 6th edition, Page no 65.

questions.text: A female patient, age 41, visits the emergency room of AIIMS with complaints of agitation, palpitations, excessive sweating, and a sense of impending doom. To rule out biological causes in an emergency, the following test should be performed:
questions.solution:
The presentation of this patient is suggestive of panic attack.

  • Before diagnosing a panic attack, we must rule out organic (medical) causes of anxiety. All the investigations listed above are important to rule out organic causes.
  • Although anemia can also present with panic attacks, Hemoglobin need not be done as an emergency investigation.
  • The most important investigation to be done here is ECG.
  • Hypoglycemia can be ruled out by asking a history of diabetes mellitus.


Organic causes of Anxiety:

  1. Hypoglycemia
  2. Hyperthyroidism
  3. Pheochromocytoma
  4. Cardiac- Angina/MI/MVP




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1888, 1892.

questions.text: Which of these is not included in personal history under psychiatry?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Food preference
 
  • The following points are included in the Personal History of Psychiatric History taking: -- Perinatal history, childhood history, Education and academic history, Obstetric history, occupational history, sexual and marital history, emotional problems in adolescents. These are included because the above categories act as stressors for development or aggravation of psychiatric disorders. 
  • Food preference is not typically included in personal history under psychiatry. While a patient's dietary habits may be relevant to their overall health and well-being, they are not typically considered a significant factor in their mental health

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 204, 212.

questions.text: Which of these is not true about obsession?
questions.solution:
• Obsession has been variably described as disorder or content of thought/possession of thought. However, for the above question option (1), (2), and (3) are correct statements, and hence, option (4) can be considered the incorrect and the best answer for this question.
  • Controversial: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology describes obsession as a disorder of possession of thought. Whereas, Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry (11th edition) list it under disorder of content of thought.
  • AIIMS follows Fish's Clinical Psychopathology as a Standard reference book - hence for INICET- Obessesion is disorder of the possession of thought.

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology: signs and Symptoms in Psychiatry, 4th edition, Page no 46, 87.
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 308.

questions.text: Which of these is evaluated by MMSE?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Cognition
 
  • The Mini-mental state examination(MMSE) is a 30-point questionnaire that is used extensively in clinical and research settings to measure cognitive impairment.
  • It is a screening tool for dementia. It assesses cognitive functions. The total score in MMSE is 30.
  • A score less than 27 suggests Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and less than 24 is suggestive of Dementia.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 201, 233, 1344.

questions.text: Which of these is not included in semantic memory?
questions.solution:
Events is Not included in Semantic memory. It is included in Episodic memory.
 
  • Semantic memory is one of the two types of declarative or explicit memory.
  • Semantic memory refers to general word knowledge that we have accumulated throughout our lives.
  • This general knowledge (facts, ideas, meaning and concepts) is intertwined in experience and dependent on culture.
  • Semantic memory is distinct from episodic memory, which is our memory of experiences and specific events that occur during our lives.
  • Episodic memory is responsible for storing and retrieving information about specific events that have occurred in our lives.




Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 116-117.

questions.text: Which tissue is represented by the following hematoxylin and eosin-stained biopsy?
questions.solution:
Tonsils are small mass of lymphatic tissue located in the wall of the pharynx at the rear of the throat of humans. The term is most commonly used to describe palatine tonsils.

Microscopically, the tonsil is a mass of lymphoid follicles supported on a connective tissue framework. In addition, the center of each of these nodules is densely packed with lymphocytes, and is referred to as the germinal center. 

The luminal surfaces of the tonsils are coated in non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium.


Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 77,707,708,709
